29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
Roy Lupton is out of hospital and the first

35.text:
thing he wants to do is go shooting. We have
a dazzling array of guns for you with the

41.text:
Oxford Gun Company. First, badgers, let's
put control back in the hands of the countryside.

49.text:
We have been sent a disc and a statement.
It was postmarked Essex, well outside the

55.text:
current cull area. It doesn't mention cattle.
It doesn't mention bovine TB. It talks instead

61.text:
about the damage that badgers do to wildlife
on the ground from hedgehogs, to harvest mice

68.text:
and ground nesting birds from oystercatchers
to English partridge.

72.text: It also suggests that shooting badgers.

77.text:
Badger shooting is still illegal except under
licence or if you are destroying a sick or

85.text:
injured animal. However, this film shows the
strength of feeling in the countryside about

90.text:
badgers which, protected by law, are wiping
our countryside clean at night.The over-population

97.text:
means the animals are turning up in surprising
places.

101.text:
This is a badger sett near my home in the
south west of England. It is on a road. It

109.text:
is lucky that this government calls it a badger
problem, some governments would call this

114.text:
Whatever you think of people shooting badgers
willy-nilly, the debate is currently bogged

124.text:
The farmers have a lot more to lose. Stars
such as Brian May might say he deplores it,

129.text:
but some of his animal rights activist gang
have threatened to burn down barns and superglue

135.text:
supermarket cashpoint machines in protest
against the cull. They have already spraypainted

142.text:
an office of the National Farmers' Union's
insurance arm, NFU Mutual, in Gloucestershire.

147.text:
They have threatened farmers and their families
in the cull areas and say they will wait out

152.text:
at night on roads and around setts armed with
walkie talkies in order to sabotage the cull.

161.text:
Filmmaker Chris Chapman who has spent years
recording the effect on farmers of government

167.text:
mishandling of first BSE, then Foot & Mouth
and now Bovine TB has strong views about where

174.text:
responsibility for looking after badgers should
lie.

178.text:
I mean Brian May. I have written to Brian,
I have written to him in the past. He is a

183.text:
very intelligent man, but he is missing the
point. It has become too emotive and emotion

193.text:
tends to override common sense. Common sense
tells us there is a big problem in the countryside.

200.text:
It isn't like foot and mouth because the public
can't see it. This is a hidden disease. They

206.text:
understood foot and mouth of 2001, because
when they sat down at night and watched the

211.text:
television they could see all these cattle
on burning pyres. So that was brought into

217.text:
their living room night after night. This
is a hidden disease. How do you show the public

222.text:
this disease. Very, very difficult, but it
is there. You can't deny that it is there.

227.text:
For more about Chris's work, go to BovineTB.info,
scroll right down to the bottom and click

234.text:
on a link called Bovine TB - A Way Forward.
If you are watching this on YouTube, there

239.text: is a link to Chris's latest film.

243.text:
Chris lives on Dartmoor in Devon. Despite
Fieldsports Channel's good links with the

247.text:
farming community across the South-West, we
could not find a single farmer in the cull

253.text:
area in Somerset prepared to go on camera.
All of them tell me they do not want to become

259.text:
a target. Despite what Mr May would like you
to believe, our furry friends do not die in

265.text:
their bed surrounded by their grand children.
Here is badger specialist, Richard Gard speaking

271.text:
to Chris Chapman in one of his in one of his
films about bovine TB.

276.text:
You can see the extended claws. This animal
has had a very difficult end to its life.

282.text:
It has been unable to dig properly, to forage
for its food. This is fairly typical of the

287.text:
situation we see. The sett had been impregnated
by rats, they have been feeding on the carcass.

293.text:
On the other side of this carcass is quite
badly eaten and it is possible that this one

297.text:
was dragged out by a fox. It has been nibbled
all over the place. This situation with the

302.text:
unhealthy badgers is really important to be
aware of. They don't have a simple existence

310.text: from life right through to death.

312.text:
Farmers, shooters, country people - we're
all after a healthy population of badgers

318.text:
- but you don't get that without management.
Celebrity chef Clarissa Dickson-Wright wants

323.text: healthy badgers because she likes eating them.

326.text:
When I was young, badger was still very much
eaten in country districts, quite legally

331.text:
- it would solve the badger crisis wouldn't
it - because pubs in the west country used

337.text: to have a badger ham on the bar.

341.text: Like a ham on a ...... very good it was too.

344.text: Was it fatty, in the same way?

348.text:
It had that rich depth of flavour about it.
If you think what a badger eats it is very

355.text: much on a par with a pig.

357.text:
So, what number of badgers to have? As shooters
know, wildlife management is not an exact

363.text:
science. In the fieldsports community, we
know there are a lot of foxes but we can't

368.text:
say how many, we know there are not enough
hedgehogs, and we are sure there are too many

374.text:
Scientists discovered the link between badgers
and bovine TB in the 1970s. The explosion

381.text:
in the badger population since then has meant
an explosion in bovine TB. These maps show

390.text:
This disc we were sent, Clarissa on cooking,
and the destruction of the British cattle

396.text:
herd - it's all about the same thing. It is
about putting the management of wildlife in

400.text:
the countryside back into the hands of country
people, and taking it away from the urban

408.text:
Now from a hot news topic to David with the
Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

422.text:
British shooters face a double whammy from
antis over lead shot. The Wildfowl & Wetlands

427.text:
Trust says that 10% of birds die from eating
lead shot, which is now banned for wildfowling

433.text:
in England and Wales, and banned over wetlands
in Scotland and Northern Ireland. Meanwhile,

438.text:
the Food Standards Agency has advised pregnant
women and children to cut down on game meat

443.text:
because of the risk of eating lead shot. The
European Food Safety Authority says the greatest

449.text:
source of lead in food is from cereals and
potatoes and BASC points out that, pound-for-pound,

455.text: there is more lead in chocolate than game.

458.text:
American states are gearing up for the pheasant
shooting season - and it's all paid for by

464.text:
the government. In one state alone, the Ohio
Department of Natural Resources' Division

469.text:
of Wildlife has released 15,000 pheasants
at 28 public hunting areas. It's youth-only

476.text:
shoots for the last two weekends of October
with the stateside seasons starting in November.

484.text:
The RSPB has awarded its top prize for farming
to the owner of a well-known shoot The 2012

490.text:
RSPB Nature of Farming award goes to Henry
Edmunds from the Cholderton Estate in Wiltshire,

495.text:
a well-known partridge shoot, with three other
shoots making the final selection.

501.text:
The number of wild salmon caught and then
released in Scotland last year is the sixth

506.text:
highest on record, according to the Scottish
government. Recorded since 1952, the figures

512.text:
show 87,915 salmon were caught by rod in 2011.
Sea trout catches have declined since the

520.text:
1950s, but the government says the 23,324
caught last year is 4% higher than the previous

528.text:
five-year average. Numbers of salmon and trout
caught in net fisheries continue to fall.

535.text:
Mark Gilchrist is an ‘appy' man. Our report
on his new hunting app, which records where

541.text:
you shot your rabbit, fox or deer, has led
to hundreds of you paying £2.99 and downloading

546.text:
it to your phones, for which he says thanks
very much. There is even talk of organisations

551.text:
here and as far away as Australia using an
adapted version of the app. If you want to

556.text:
find out more, click here to watch the film.
Mark is asking people with iphones to be patient.

562.text: That version should be available very soon.

566.text:
And finally, a man got the wrong side of a
rutting red stag in a park in London. Luckily

571.text:
he was on the right side of the tree. After
several minutes of here-we-go-round-the-mulberry-bush,

576.text:
the film posted on YouTube shows our hapless
townie escaping upwards.

580.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

588.text: Now with the map that matters it is calendar.

595.text:
Welcome to Calendar for those important dates
for the diary and those seasonal reminders.

600.text:
Moon is waning crescent, with nights getting
darker and heading for a new moon on Monday

604.text:
15th October, so a bit of wild weather over
the weekend could make for exciting wildfowling.

610.text:
The best of the wildfowling and gooseshooting
is still in the North East of England and

614.text:
along the East Coast of Scotland as birds
start coming in from their summering grounds

618.text: in what is already becoming the frozen north.

622.text:
Game shooting is underway all over the UK
with released birds reportedly on average

627.text:
smaller than usual because of the rain earlier
in the year. The lack of moon should be good

635.text:
On the deerstalking front, we are between
the best of the fallow rut and the best of

639.text:
the red rut, though lots of wildlife activity
has been later than usual this year all over

647.text:
There are still plenty of country events to
enjoy, including the Tackle & Gun trade show

652.text: this weekend at Stoneleigh Park, Warwickshire.

657.text:
Are you going to be in the Essex area on 25th
October 2012? That's next Thursday week. Independent

663.text:
Shooting Supplies in Mountnessing is holding
an open evening, starting at 5pm. The first

668.text:
10 people through the door get 20% off clothing,
footwear and accessories. The next 10 people

674.text:
get 10% off. And there is a charity raffle
- all proceeds going to Essex Air Ambulance

679.text:
- where the star prize is a day's pigeonshooting
with our own legendary Andy Crow. Other prizes

685.text:
include cartridges and a shooting lesson with
former England team member Tracy Ridington.

690.text:
The evening goes on until 9pm and includes
wine and cheese. So don't forget. Independent

695.text:
Shooting Supplies - Mountnessing - Essex - 25th
October. For more information call Andrew

711.text:
Also if you are in or near Wiltshire on Friday
12th October, there is a charity clay pigeon

715.text:
shoot at Winkworth Farm, Lea, near Malmesbury,
with six stands of team flushes and on Saturday

721.text:
13th October, the Schools Challenge Winter
series is offering 50 sporting at the Oxford

726.text:
Gun Company. You will see more from the Oxford
Gun Company later in the programme.

732.text:
That was this week's Calendar. And if you
have an event that needs a plug on next week's

742.text:
Thank you David. Like Fiona Bruce, but no,
come to think of it not really. Now Roy Lupton

749.text:
has recently come round from an operation
and he wants to go shooting.

756.text:
The road to recovery can be a long boring
trip - so just a week after hip replacement

762.text:
surgery Roy has plans to get out and about
as quickly as possible, especially as it's

768.text:
one of his favourite times of year - the fallow
rut...but first he needs to learn how to walk

775.text:
before he can run, probably not the best turn
of phrase! We start with pimping his ride

784.text:
As long as my surgeon, my physiotherapists
and all the nurses on the ward don't find

789.text:
out we should be ok. Obviously it looks a
little bit ludicrous what we have done here

792.text:
and just set up, but it does have a serious
side I promise you that. What I wanted to

797.text:
do was just practise shooting from the wheelchair
so we have made a bit of a Heath Robinson

803.text:
attempt at making a bit of a rest so we have
cable tied a few sturdy sticks and used my

810.text:
rest which usually goes on the side of the
truck. So we are going to have a bit of a

813.text:
play and see if I can shoot straight with
it. Hopefully the morphine hasn't taken too

817.text:
much of a toll on my shooting skills and we
will see how we do.

821.text:
So his accuracy is OK - but he's got to move
up to a .243, plus get close enough,while

827.text:
rumbling through a wood in a wheel chair to
get a chance of a clear shot.

832.text:
Roy's also got to find someone who is willing
to take him stalking. His consultant has told

837.text:
him no bumping around ..of any kind.... for
6 weeks..so we'll just have to let him stew

844.text: until he gets the all clear..

846.text:
Right... two weeks have passed and Roy has
been given permission to drive - He can get

852.text:
to his shooting ground but he can't load bear
- This means crutches to get through the really

857.text: rough stuff and a wheel chair in the wood...

860.text:
I have finally managed to get out and I have
got the cure for cabin fever so I am heading

872.text:
out to just one of my little spots where there
is normally a bit of deer activity on. Unfortunately

875.text:
with this one it is all the apples in one
basket because we are just going to go to

876.text:
one stand and sit there and wait and hope.
There is definitely no chance of stalking

880.text:
through the woods tonight, but it is a damn
sight better than sitting in and watching

883.text: the television and going stir crazy at home

886.text:
Roy's chair does make a bit of a rumble in
the jungle but he gets himself into a position

891.text:
where a group of does are 100 or so yards
ahead of up through the wood. He is not using

897.text:
the sticks gaffer-taped to the chair and instead
chooses to use his faithful shooting sticks

902.text:
which drop to a comfortable level. With them
firmly planted he doesn't think he'll being

909.text:
Where we are at the moment, we were just coming
in on an old rutting stand and we were going

911.text:
along really slowly and all of a sudden we
have come into a big group of deer. There

915.text:
is now a deer which has moved in on our right.
There is a buck, there is 2 bucks having a

919.text:
bit of a spar and one buck rubbing here and
a big group of does there. But we are literally

925.text:
pinned to the spot at the moment. I daren't
move, just see what pans out. The only trouble

944.text:
is we are going to be running out of light
in about 20 minutes so we just hope something

945.text:
What we hope will walk by is a pricket - however
we get something or someone else instead - a

951.text:
dog walker passes between us and the group
of deer. ..Roy is really disappointed..and

958.text:
frustrated that people don't stick to the
footpaths.

961.text:
Again there is no footpath here at all. Yet
again we have got another dog walker who is

968.text:
Roy doesn't shout out as there is a slim chance
there's a buck to the left of us - we leave

971.text:
the wood and Roy perches on the crutches to
do some calling - it's last chance saloon.

975.text:
We are on a part of the estate where there
shouldn't be anybody at all. There are no

982.text:
footpaths, no public access what so ever.
I am on one of the main rutting stands on

984.text:
the far part of the estate and all of a sudden
you get a guy walking past with his bright

992.text:
blue top on and his dog. With this fading
light you really have to be careful. So again

993.text:
you have to rely on your optics and in this
half hour of last light it really does pay

998.text:
to have good optics and see what is going
on.

1008.text:
Roy hasn't made all this effort not to give
it his best shot and he heads over to the

1012.text:
other side of this patch of ground to see
if we can catch up with a fox we filmed a

1016.text:
few weeks ago - This time Roy sets himself
up on the bonnet -

1020.text:
The calling works a treat - the Taclight torch
picks up some eyes but he runs but stops for

1027.text: a second glance - Roy takes his chance..

1031.text:
Oh that was so nice. We had a very quick response
from that fox coming in there. That was absolutely

1043.text:
superb. Definitely a cure for cabin fever.
Two or two and half weeks locked in doors

1048.text:
and a lot of bed rest and a lot of sitting
there. It has got its bonuses, a lot of people

1054.text:
have been round and bringing me around grapes
and making me cups of tea and whatever else.

1059.text:
Dom you have been noted in your absence. It
is absolutely superb to come out and above

1065.text:
all else really it is nice to know that everybody
out there cares and wants you to get back

1071.text:
to it. Right shall we go and pick that fox
up.

1074.text:
Although we can't be a hundred percent certain,
there's a really good chance this is the one

1081.text:
Now I think this is actually the fox that
we had come up to us on camera when David

1087.text:
and I had a bit of a breakdown in communication
and what I wanted to do was see if we could

1091.text:
catch up with him, because I knew pretty much
where he would be and the field we are in

1097.text:
now is just overlooking the wood where we
called him in before. So what I wanted to

1101.text:
do this time was start off with a different
call, as he already knew the call I was using

1105.text:
previously. So just kicked off with another
call, a slightly lighter call. So it is not

1110.text:
quite as harsh. And all of a sudden it came
bolting out from the brambles. It looks like

1116.text:
it could be, it is very, very difficult to
say obviously. It is definitely the same territory.

1122.text: It could be the lad who got away.

1125.text:
The healing process can be a long and difficult
one - and the medical world often find that

1131.text:
animal contact can speed things along. This
fox ain't no dolphin but it certainly got

1136.text: Roy's mojo firing on all cylinders once again.

1141.text:
From rifles to shot guns and we are at the
Oxford Gun Company, where we have a large

1149.text:
It's all happening here at the Oxford Gun
Company today. They are having an open day

1154.text:
to start the game season. Representatives
from AYA, Rizzini, Browning, Beretta and Miroku

1161.text:
are showing off their products. And that's
not all. There are the Winter Schools Challenge

1166.text:
and the Game Compact Sporting competitions,
too.

1170.text:
The Oxford Gun Company is at the forefront
of promoting shooting to all. So, what a good

1175.text:
place for companies such as Browning and AYA
to come and show off the cream of their merchandise.

1181.text:
They are hoping it's going to be bang-bang-ker-ching!
The family firm has set up a day that allows

1187.text:
customers to try the guns before they buy.
Plus they'll get a little free tuition when

1193.text:
Vaughn and son Charlie are trying out the
Beretta A400. They are torn between Browning

1199.text:
and Beretta. After much deliberation and negotiation
the Beretta is the one they go for.

1204.text:
Yes, we just bought a Beretta A400 Semiautomatic.
My son Charlie, he is 13. He has been shooting

1211.text:
with a 12 bore over and under for the last
6 months. After about 50 or 60 shots it starts

1216.text:
to make his shoulder quite sore, but with
a gas operated semi-automatic there is no

1221.text:
recoil very much. A bit more lenient on the
shoulder. So we have come along and had a

1225.text:
look at a couple of guns and chosen the Beretta
A400.

1229.text:
Edward King is here today representing ASI,
which is the company that brings the AYA marque

1234.text:
from Spain to an adoring public in the UK.
Currently it is not selling through the Oxford

1238.text:
The main strength of both Rizzini and AYA
is that they are both able to attend to small

1242.text:
details which make a gun specific and tailored
to the individual's requirements. So unlike

1250.text:
mass produced off the shelf guns these can
be really guns that suit you down to a T.

1257.text:
Ask anyone - most people own either a Beretta
or a Browning. Vaughn and Charlie might like

1263.text:
their new Beretta but most people who walk
out of the Oxford Gun Company with a shiny

1267.text: new gun walk out with a Browning.

1270.text:
We have had a mixed bag of people today, predominantly
game shooters. So we have been showing them

1275.text:
a range of game guns and the most interest
I think today has been with our heritage gun

1280.text:
which is our top of the range production gun
in 12 gauge and 20 gauge and that has had

1286.text:
While the gun reps are sweetening the customers
back at the shop, out in the field we have

two competitions under way: the Winter Schools

1297.text:
Got a new thing. One of our instructors, Robert
he actually came up with the idea, that as

1302.text:

1308.text:
gamey type targets for game shooters to come

1313.text:
their gun away at the end of the season and
they don't touch it for a year. They need

1317.text:
to go out get some shells down the gun, get
shooting so that when you are out on the field

1322.text:
you have actually got a bit of experience
how to shoot a pheasant or a partridge.

Will Ford, James Lewis and Sam Clark, keen

I had a friend who is a member here of the

Then I got introduced to the instructors and
they took me on another day's course and I

don't know much about nowhunting as we're
